In 1983 or 1984, I was in attendance at the Naval War College in Newport, RI, where John Young gave a speech.  I was in junior high school and obsessed about space travel.  I wish I could remember specifically what he discussed.  It was either shortly before or after his last mission STS-9 in November and December of 1983.  I imagine he was on a public relations tour for the Space Shuttle program.  I was there with my stepmother, who taught high school astronomy.  I still have the outstanding book I got that night:  "NASA, the First 25 Years, 1958-1983 (A Resource for Teachers) -- A Curriculum Project."  I found two used copies for sale on Amazon:  one for $4 and the other for $927!
R.I.P John Young you will be in our hearts and memories
In addition to all this, Young would have commanded the Hubble deployment mission, had it not been for the Challenger disaster.

During STS-1, Young's heart rate during launch was around 68 bpm. He said he was just too old to care and that the "view hasn't changed much" when he looked down at Earth from orbit. In contrast, Robert Crippen had a heart rate almost twice as much as Young's during launch.

I read someplace when John Young was interviewed, he pointed to a huge stack of books and manuals he worked with in 1970s preparing for Shuttle. Imagine developing/learning all those systems that was built from scratch, working with all kinds of people defining requirements, flight profiles, procedures. STS-1 patch shows Shuttle lifting off and orbiter going around the world. I heard if they can get it off the pad and orbit once, then that would be considered meeting much of the mission objectives. Fortunately it was a two-day mission. Then Young gets to command STS-9 Spacelab, I heard there was a fire in aft compartment during entry, it went out. Anyone care to comment? I'm too lazy to look up the details. Let's see, Young commanded Gemini 12, Apollo 16, STS 1 and 9. Any other astronauts commanded that many missions?

John Young, Joe Engle, and Story Musgrave are the ultimate "steely-eyed missile men" of NASA.

Young for all the reasons mentioned.

Joe Engle for being the only person (to date) to have flown two different winged craft into space - the X-15 by the US Air Force's 50 mile definition, rather than IAU's 100 km - and the second Space Shuttle mission. In addition, during STS-2, he became the only person in the history of the Shuttle program to manually fly the shuttle from orbit all the way to landing. Every other landing was done at least partially under computer control. And he wasn't "gentle" during reentry - he flew it to the very edges of what it could do, specifically to test the limits of the Shuttle before future "operational" missions. STS-2's reentry and approach was almost certainly the most hazardous (planned) act of the entire Shuttle program.

Story Musgrave was the "cool as ice" veteran of six Space Shuttle missions, has six college degrees (including as a medical doctor,) was intimately involved with the design of Skylab as well as the EVA suits for the Space Shuttle, was instrumental in the repair of Hubble, and, for his "cool as ice" moniker, he wasn't strapped in for one of his flights' reentry, he was standing up in the cockpit so he could record video of the plasma streaming over the Shuttle during reentry. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TOieURpnbm0 . Lastly, he is the only astronaut to have flown on every one of the Space Shuttles, Columbia, Atlantis, Challenger, Discovery, and Endeavour.

comment_text: John Young also has a really great sense of humor too. He will be terribly missed :'(

Nice tribute. Regarding the sandwich on Gemini 3, Mary Roach mentioned in her book "Packing For Mars" it was not something major except for media coverage. However, I read that some managers and congressmen got pretty upset, felt they are losing control of the astronauts so after that no more spacecraft after Molly Brown had names. Names returned during Apollo 9 when there's two different manned spacecraft flying at same time. Getting to fly on first Gemini mission was a huge plus, that program is what put US way ahead of Soviet Union (fuel cells, onboard computer, ability to change orbits, dock with other spacecraft). Gus and Young probably had to squeeze in a lot of tests during their brief flight. Besides using a name to help it be unsinkable, Gus didn't want to experience what he had on his Mercury flight.

What is amazing is John Young stayed active at NASA for decades. Rumor has it he was too outspoken after Challenger accident but he maintained astronaut status mentally and physically when others would simply retire. He was not flamboyant, and in many ways "boring." I remember distinctly watching on TV the STS-1 landing where he exited Columbia with that "Yeah!" attitude walking all around full of excitement. Crippen said before they opened the hatch John was jumping all over inside the orbiter (unusual for this "boring" astronaut). Getting back to Apollo 16, Houston radioed to Young and Duke when they were on the lunar surface the Shuttle program was approved by congress. Nearly ten years later, and lots of studying and sim time, Young was able to command the first and successful STS mission.

Beside the sandwich on Gemini 3, they had Young and Duke drink a lot of orange juice on Apollo 16. While EVA, John wasn't aware audio feed to earth was hot complained about farting and other stuff, "I'm never going to eat another F orange again." But at that point media didn't bother to tune into the audio feed (walking on the Moon at that time was considered boring that would have low viewer readings).

Also note John Young did flight tests of the new F4 Phantom before becoming an astronaut.

Remember listening to every minute of the audio from Gemini 3 as a kid.  John Young was always, and will continue to be, a role model.   I wrote NASA as the last shuttle mission approached, suggesting they make it an all veteran crew, with John Young commanding.  That would have been excellent.

My dad retired Air Force in 1969 to go to NASA-JSC to work on Apollo.  Though I loved Apollo, I loved the Shuttle even more.  As a favor, my dad gave me a frames photos of the launch and landing of STS-1.  The launch photo is signed by the crew of STS-1 and STS-2 (including John Young).  Wish I knew a way to send you a photo.  I also have a Apollo 15 Flight Plan, a Apollo CSM Contactor's Model, and a few other items.  Oh, and Jim Irwin was in our church; so, when we signed a covenant (promise) to pray for him while he was on Apollo 15 and he left a copy on the moon; so, my signature is on the moon.  I have a copy of what we left and I hope one day one of my descendants can go there and see it.
